channel.title: Comments on: Future priorities for Open Science

item.title: By: protohedgehog
item.dc:creator: protohedgehog
item.description:
In reply to <a href="http://fossilsandshit.com/future-priorities-for-open-science/#comment-6532">Jay Patel</a>.
Great comment, thanks Jay! In short, yes, I agree! Open access does not imply open accessibility :)
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Jay Patel.

Great comment, thanks Jay! In short, yes, I agree! Open access does not imply open accessibility ðŸ™‚

item.title: By: Jay Patel
item.dc:creator: Jay Patel
item.description: Great suggestions here! I would add that open science as a construct should be broadened so that it includes science communication much more. A great deal of emphasis is placed on publishing more open-access papers, but we often don't consider that many people (outside of healthcare and very technical settings) are uninterested in poring over scientific papers. But if these OA papers were written to be "cognitively open" or learnable, then it would take scientific communication/literacy into a Golden Age. I have a few ideas about how to go about this...
item.content:encoded: Great suggestions here! I would add that open science as a construct should be broadened so that it includes science communication much more. A great deal of emphasis is placed on publishing more open-access papers, but we often don’t consider that many people (outside of healthcare and very technical settings) are uninterested in poring over scientific papers. But if these OA papers were written to be “cognitively open” or learnable, then it would take scientific communication/literacy into a Golden Age. I have a few ideas about how to go about this…
